unnormalised: ## The Great Indian Jugaad: How We Handle Money Matters
normalised: ## The Great Indian Jugaad: How We Handle Money Matters

unnormalised: Let's be honest, when it comes to money, we Indians are the ultimate juggadus. We can stretch a rupee further than you can stretch that Yoga instructor in your building. Forget fancy budgeting apps, our brain is the original Excel sheet. And banking? Well, that's an adventure in itself.
normalised: Let's be honest, when it comes to money, we Indians are the ultimate juggadus. We can stretch a rupee further than you can stretch that Yoga instructor in your building. Forget fancy budgeting apps, our brain is the original Excel sheet. And banking? Well, that's an adventure in itself.

unnormalised: Remember when online banking felt like diffusing a bomb? Entering your username, password, that OTP that took longer to arrive than your online order – it was a high-stakes game! And God forbid you typed the wrong number in your UPI ID. Suddenly, Rs. 5000 is winging its way to some random Sharma uncle in Patna instead of your chai-samosa fund. Let’s not even get started on remembering which pin to use for which card.
normalised: Remember when online banking felt like diffusing a bomb? Entering your username, password, that O-T-P that took longer to arrive than your online order – it was a high-stakes game! And God forbid you typed the wrong number in your U-P-I I-D. Suddenly, rupees five thousand is winging its way to some random Sharma uncle in Patna instead of your chai-samosa fund. Let’s not even get started on remembering which pin to use for which card.

unnormalised: Speaking of Sharma uncle, you know he’s still rocking that passbook, diligently updating it every month at the local branch. “Digital India? Humbug!” he probably grumbles while waiting in line behind 17 other equally skeptical uncles. It’s tradition, you see. It’s like Diwali cleaning, you just *have* to do it. My own Dadi still insists on hiding her ₹2000 notes in the atta dabba. Can't argue with that kind of security, can you?

unnormalised: And then there’s the art of negotiating. Whether it's Rs. 50 off that saree or ₹10 less for those bananas, we are born negotiators. It’s practically in our DNA. Bargaining is our national sport, and the currency is our playing field. I mean, who pays full price anyway? Even at "fixed price" shops, we give it a shot. "Bhaiya, kuch toh kam karo?"

unnormalised: Cash is still king, of course. Especially for those "under the table" deals (wink, wink). Need a plumber? Cash. Auto-rickshaw? Cash. That questionable street food? Definitely cash (and a prayer). Try offering UPI to the paanwala, he’ll probably stare at you like you’ve offered him a Bitcoin. You might even get a lecture on the perils of "digital money" while he’s at it! And don't even suggest paying Rs. 2 in change via Paytm. You will be publicly shamed.

unnormalised: Let's not forget the gold obsession. Buying gold on Akshaya Tritiya is practically mandatory. It’s like investing in happiness, packaged in shiny yellow metal. Who cares if the interest rates on those gold bonds are lower than a limbo dancer? It's gold, baby! It's an heirloom, a status symbol, and a solid investment all rolled into one. And who are we to break tradition?

unnormalised: So, whether you're hoarding ₹10 coins “just in case”, haggling over the price of vegetables, or navigating the treacherous waters of online banking, remember that you’re part of a long and hilarious tradition. Embrace the chaos, celebrate the frugality, and laugh all the way to the… well, probably just the nearest ATM. Because, let's face it, cash is still king. Especially if you want that extra gol gappa from the street vendor for free. Worth Rs. 15, easily. ;)
